sentences.sentence: Readers mostly excoriate and urge alternatives to what one calls “these obnoxious, deafening, exhaust-spewing machines.” Also: The metaverse; signs of concern.To the Editor:Re “The First Thing We Do, Let's Kill All the Leaf Blowers,” by Margaret Renkl (Opinion guest essay, Oct. 26):Our town of Winnetka, Ill., has had a summer-month ban on gas-powered leaf blowers for many years that has been largely ignored by landscapers.
This past spring, local residents decided to change that.
By June, our police department had secured voluntary pledges from 35 landscapers to obey the ban.

The pledge wasn't perfect, but our town was quieter and the air cleaner than it's been for years.When people learn about how these antiquated machines harm people and the planet, there's a strong pull to do the right thing.King PoorWinnetka, Ill.To the Editor:As someone who has loathed these obnoxious, deafening, exhaust-spewing machines for years, all I can say ᅳ loudly, because of the noise ᅳ is: Yes!I would add just one thing to Margaret Renkl's case for banning these irritants.

There's an alternative to the leaf blower that is cheap, readily available and virtually silent.It's called a rake.Mark RemyPortland, Ore.To the Editor:I spent a recent autumn Sunday wandering around parts of Brooklyn.
I marveled at the ability to hear my own footfalls on the side streets, thinking how much quieter it was in the big city than in my own small town.
It was then that I realized the difference: No one was blasting those infernal leaf blowers!

It was such a joy to be able to hear yourself think.Rande BeidelRutherford, N.J.To the Editor:Margaret Renkl doesn't like leaf blowers, nor does she seem to appreciate the hard work the landscape industry does daily to care for our nation's green infrastructure.

But rest assured that the landscape industry is making the transition to zero-emissions equipment as soon as it is feasible for commercial use.In addition, new technologies like smart controllers for irrigation, robotic and battery-powered mowers, drones and soil sensors are advancing rapidly and are making the care of your yards, parks and campuses even more eco-friendly each day.Britt WoodFairfax, Va.The writer is chief executive of the National Association of Landscape Professionals.To the Editor:Margaret Renkl omitted one item from her long list of gas-powered leaf blower ills: the sorry burden they place on the low-wage workers most affected by the noise, vibration and pollution emitted by these destructive machines.Paul OppenheimPownal, MaineTo the Editor:It is not only in the autumn that we are subjected to horrific noise and air pollution, but also during the summer months when the roars of gas-driven lawn mowers and leaf blowers offensively punctuate the lazy, hazy days.
And what about the winter months with the blaring gas-powered snow blowers?

All the noise is enough to raise one's blood pressure.Until lawmakers find a way to ban these health and environmental menaces, I will wear my earphones to listen to some calming music.Frances R. CurcioStaten IslandTo the Editor:I'll give you my leaf blower when you pry it from my cold, dead hands.William BlalockDeland, Fla.Metaverse NightmaresTo the Editor:Re “Metaverse?
Are You Kidding Me?

!,” by Charles M. Blow (column, Nov. 1):Mark Zuckerberg's suggestion that we should now spend our time in a virtual world is most timely, if by “timely” we mean: at the worst possible moment.Our real world is creating diseases like Covid-19.
In our real world, what we used to consider rare disasters are now frequent disasters.
Right now, we must face our actual world and decide how to deal with it.
But our Facebook prophet says: No!

It's time to escape.I do not know whether all the ideas about this virtual world are new, but I imagine that some of them were cribbed from a memo that began, “Dear Nero, here's what to do while Rome burns.”Our greatest artists, over hundreds of years, have struggled to convey the most frightening image of the horrors of Hell.

This imagined virtual world in which we will “socialize,” buy and play, where we will have nothing to fear but hackers and the effects of Facebook's moderation and A.I., is likely to trump them all.Tobias D. RobisonPrinceton, N.J.To the Editor:Dear Mr. Blow: Thank you for helping me continue disengaging from the social media world.Jacqueline NowakDayton, Ohio'In This House': Signs of ConcernTo the Editor:In “The Curious, Persistent Power of a Yard Sign That Went Viral” (Critic's Notebook, front page, Oct. 31), Amanda Hess writes, “With its exhaustive list of allied issues,” the “In This House” sign “diffuses the owner's perceived responsibility to engage in any particular movement.”That seems unfair.
I also think there is way more behind these signs than liberal white women in the midst of a crisis both political and cultural.

The sign owners are better thought of as concerned citizens, cognizant and outraged at the economic, social and civic ills in our country.To me these signs are a lovely antidote to the reasons they exist ᅳ the increase in overt racism, misogyny, science denial and a disregard of the truth.And the sign's kicker ᅳ what Ms. Hess calls the “sanctimonious final line” ᅳ “Kindness Is Everything”?
Bring it on!Kathy LottyFairfield, Conn.PHOTO:    (PHOTOGRAPH BY Tom Williams/Roll Call/Getty Images FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
